Dialogue: Johnson, isn't it? Have you an appointment?

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: Want me to beg?

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: I told you, Kings don't beg.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: I believe this time a bit of begging might be required. Elizabeth says I must eat humble crow.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Its "crow" or "humble pie". Take your pick.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: I was frightened and took refuge in being `Royal'. What I said was unforgivable. And...

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: And?

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: What's the one essential thing a King must do? He must believe he is King. How can I possibly do that? For pity sake, Lionel, I beg you: get me through! I'll pay you another shilling.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: What're friends for?

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: I wouldn't know.

Speaker: myrtle
Dialogue: I've got the boys sorting their things. Your office will be a chore...

Speaker: cosmo lang
Dialogue: We asked to see Your Highness because there's the urgent question of what to call your brother. Aside from the obvious.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: What do you suggest?

Speaker: cosmo lang
Dialogue: Mr. Edward Windsor? All he deserves.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: What has my brother given up on his abdication, other than the throne?

Speaker: winston churchill
Dialogue: Very well, Lord E.W. it is.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: And as a Lord of the realm, he's entitled to be elected to the House of Commons. Heading a King's Party.

Speaker: cosmo lang
Dialogue: Unacceptable!

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: So you prefer he takes a seat in the House of Lords? Again, on behalf of a King's Party? Is that acceptable?

Speaker: winston churchill
Dialogue: Certainly not.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: But if he's made a Royal Duke, and called His Royal Highness, he cannot stand for Parliament. Nor may he speak or vote in the House of Lords.

Speaker: cosmo lang
Dialogue: Oh I say...

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: The Duke of Windsor it is. Gentlemen.

Speaker: winston churchill
Dialogue: Not exactly a dummy, is he?

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Splendid. Here's another. "She sifted seven thick-stalked thistles through strong thick sieves." At home, twenty-five times, in rapid succession.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: Those are my hardest sounds.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Shall we invite your wife in now?

Speaker: myrtle
Dialogue: Milady?

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: "Your Majesty", the first time. After that, "Ma'am". Not Malm as in Palm, Mam as in ham. I'm informed your husband calls my husband Bertie and my husband calls your husband Lionel. I trust, however, you won't attempt to call me Liz.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: How're they getting on?

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: As to be expected.

Speaker: myrtle
Dialogue: You may call me "Madam Logue".

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Thank you, Madame Logue, but I'm waiting to be summoned.

Speaker: myrtle
Dialogue: You don't like my husband. That's what I was told.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: I was told the same.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: Do we remain in hiding?

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: I'm not going out there!

Speaker: myrtle
Dialogue: What do you dislike about my Lionel?

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: I don't wish my husband to be demeaned. What don't you like about mine?

Speaker: myrtle
Dialogue: I don't want my Lionel getting hurt.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: There's only one thing can save him now: success.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: We're being cowards.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Of course. We're sensible men.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: You should go in.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Me? You.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: Why me?!

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: You're the Royal.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: Being a monarchist, I recognize these are your digs. Therefore: here you rule. Therefore: you go in.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Oh! Hello, Lady Elizabeth! Oh! Hello, Myrtle darling! What a pleasant surprise.

Speaker: myrtle
Dialogue: Will the Yorks be staying for dinner?

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: A previous engagement.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Some other time, love.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Harley Street is far too public. What is my function here?

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: For me to show you how to pitch in.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Oh dear, I may not be a `pitch in' type.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Piece of cake.  Please assume a supine position on the floor.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: What?!

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Firm support is needed.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: Full of hot air.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Well on your way to becoming a qualified political speaker. Again...

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Good grief.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Gently of course.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Are you alright, Bertie?

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Now exhale slowly...down goes Princess Elizabeth...inhale slowly...nothing rushed, expanding your chest fully, extending the column of air til it hits the diaphragm...and...up comes Princess Elizabeth. Exhale...down goes Princess Elizabeth...inhale...up comes Princess Elizabeth. You get the idea. Doesn't have to be Princess Elizabeth of course, but I thought you'd prefer your wife to one of the staff. Now comes the fun part.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: There's actually more?

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: You will now shout the vowel sounds, all five of them, as loudly as possible, each to last no less than 15 seconds. There's poor coordination between your larynx and diaphragm. Princess Elizabeth, you can be the official timer.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Vowel sounds? Shouted at an open window? On a public street?

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Anyone who can stand at an open window vibrating loudly in full view of the world can learn to give a public speech.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: They can also be considered quite dotty. Don't even contemplate it!

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: Sorry, dear, doctor's orders. Aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa...  She's right, those two chaps are staring at me.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: They're always looking at you.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: You're followed?

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Royal scrutiny, Doctor, best get used to it.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: ...aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaayyyyyyyyyyy... ...eeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeee...  Are you timing this? iiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiii... ooooooooooooooooooooooooo... uuuuuuuuuuu.

Speaker: valentine
Dialogue: May we be excused?

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: We don't want to hear you fight.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: We're not fighting. Your mother isn't talking.

Speaker: myrtle
Dialogue: You wish me to speak my mind?

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Boys, leave.

Speaker: the boys
Dialogue: Thank you, Dad! Thank you, Mum!

Speaker: myrtle
Dialogue: Lionel...without warning, I arrive home to find the Queen in my parlour.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: A Duchess, she hasn't been crowned yet.

Speaker: myrtle
Dialogue: Lionel, don't quibble!

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: What'd you think of her?

Speaker: myrtle
Dialogue: Does it matter!? She's the Queen and he's the King forgodsake! What're they doing here?!

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Why'd you come home so early?

Speaker: myrtle
Dialogue: Lionel...

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: They came for help.

Speaker: myrtle
Dialogue: What role are you auditioning for now? Royal saviour?! Who's going to help us?! This will bring us down, Lionel. You know it will.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: When that poor chap first walked into my office, he was a slim, quiet man with tired eyes and all the outward symptoms of the person upon whom a habitual speech defect has set the sign. You saw him today; once more there was hope.

Speaker: myrtle
Dialogue: You're not listening to me!

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Myrtle, I love you.

Speaker: myrtle
Dialogue: You say that, but you don't listen when I say, in so many ways, how desperately I want to go home, how I never, ever, intended to stay here. This was to be a holiday trip to see `Mother England', and you turned it into quite something else. What happened, Lionel? We went to Wembley Stadium, next thing...you'd cashed in our tickets.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Myrtle... I don't deserve a wonderful woman like you.

Speaker: myrtle
Dialogue: How right you are.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: But why'd you come home so early?

Speaker: myrtle
Dialogue: Lionel...I was let go.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Why?!

Speaker: myrtle
Dialogue: They're frightened, Lionel. Of what seems so far above them. I sympathize. I'm frightened too.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Oh, Myrtle. My love...

Speaker: winston churchill
Dialogue: Only the vulgar ones.

Speaker: cosmo lang
Dialogue: Let's sincerely hope.

Speaker: winston churchill
Dialogue: Is this a `slightly pregnant pause'?

Speaker: cosmo lang
Dialogue: They say he is dim.

Speaker: winston churchill
Dialogue: Demonstrably untrue.

Speaker: cosmo lang
Dialogue: They say he has epilepsy.

Speaker: winston churchill
Dialogue: Patently erroneous.

Speaker: cosmo lang
Dialogue: Fragile, prone to illness...

Speaker: winston churchill
Dialogue: Some correctness in that.

Speaker: cosmo lang
Dialogue: ...and will die prematurely. They predict he'll be unable to complete the Coronation.

Speaker: winston churchill
Dialogue: What do you propose? Shorten the ceremony? Or no ceremony at all?

Speaker: cosmo lang
Dialogue: My idea exactly!

Speaker: winston churchill
Dialogue: I believed so. But what we need is a pageant of pomp and pomposity to impress the world.

Speaker: cosmo lang
Dialogue: What we need, and what we'll get, may be two rather different things. Did you hear his pathetic attempt at the Accession Council? He'll never be able to speak in public.

Speaker: winston churchill
Dialogue: So, we plonk a tinsel crown on his head and lock him in a closet? Who then will spiritually lead this great nation into war? Who will address the far flung corners of the Empire, rallying all to our defense?

Speaker: cosmo lang
Dialogue: Well...

Speaker: winston churchill
Dialogue: The Head of our Church? Is that what you have in mind?

Speaker: cosmo lang
Dialogue: Would it be such a calamity?

Speaker: winston churchill
Dialogue: Best ask our new King.

Speaker: cosmo lang
Dialogue: Your Majesty.

Speaker: winston churchill
Dialogue: Excuse me, sir, duty calls.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: Is this the scene of the crime?

Speaker: cosmo lang
Dialogue: What a peculiar thing to say.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: Referring to my assault upon the ears of the listeners.

Speaker: cosmo lang
Dialogue: Ah, yes, wireless is indeed a Pandora's Box. I have, however, categorically said no to the BBC's new "radio-with-pictures" gadget. Imagine, the unwashed viewing us as we blow our noses or scratch our bottoms.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: Radio with pictures?!

Speaker: cosmo lang
Dialogue: It is called..."television". Happily, with a transmission range of only fifteen miles this "TV" thing has no future. We shall, however, be forced to permit cinema; the product of which I shall personally edit.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: That'll keep you busy, removing all my stops and starts.

Speaker: cosmo lang
Dialogue: Unless of course you'd prefer a quiet ceremony?

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: What exactly do you mean?

Speaker: cosmo lang
Dialogue: Something...discreet...private. We could pre-record an edited version to be broadcast to the world. Or even find an actor with a similar voice.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: A King based upon deception?

Speaker: cosmo lang
Dialogue: If your gentleman from Security would give us space, we could discuss this in private.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: You mean my bodyguard,"Crusher?"

Speaker: cosmo lang
Dialogue: Fret not. As I assured our nation in my recent broadcast: "When his people listen to their new Monarch they will note an occasional momentary hesitation in his speech. But to those who hear it, it need cause no sort of embarrassment, for it causes none to him who speaks." You see, I've paved the way. But should you wish to avoid further stress...

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Why not paint him pink and cover him with sequins?

Speaker: cosmo lang
Dialogue: Pardon?!

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: If you wish to call attention to his anxiety.

Speaker: cosmo lang
Dialogue: Does your bodyguard know to whom he's speaking? He certainly doesn't know his place!

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: Doctor Lionel Logue, my speech therapist.

Speaker: cosmo lang
Dialogue: Therapist?! I'd no idea! Had I known Your Majesty was seeking assistance I would've made my own recommendation.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: Dr. Logue is to be present at the Coronation.

Speaker: cosmo lang
Dialogue: Impossibly to find room. Even for a Doctor.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Just Lionel.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: Behind the chair of Edward the Confessor.

Speaker: cosmo lang
Dialogue: The Royal Box!? Your Family will be seated there.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: Which makes it most suitable.

Speaker: cosmo lang
Dialogue: Perhaps I might be able to add a very small stool.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: Two comfortable chairs. One for Madam Logue. She's a close friend of my wife. The Queen.

Speaker: cosmo lang
Dialogue: I'll have someone attend to it.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: And now, if you don't mind, we need the premises.

Speaker: cosmo lang
Dialogue: My dear fellow, this is Westminster Abbey! The Church must make preparations.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: So must Bertie.

Speaker: cosmo lang
Dialogue: Bertie?! We do not call the King: "Bertie"!

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: I do. During waking hours we'll need the facilities. It'll be a closed set. No observers.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: Those are my wishes, Your Grace.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Wouldn't want him as a friend.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: And don't ever call me Bertie in public.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Tell me...

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: I sense one of your dreadful questions on the horizon.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Do you really want to be King?

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: Knew it! I haven't any choice.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: You can be a wounded King who stumbles through his Coronation. Or, as the Arch of C so archly suggests, no Coronation at all. Always a choice.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: What's this, you wait til Westminster Abbey, then ambush me?

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: I'm simply asking questions... which you seem unable to answer.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: I'm a sacrificial lamb being led to slaughter! Damn you!

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Quite possibly. But at least I know what I want. You haven't the foggiest.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: I WANT TO BE HEARD!

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: That's quite different. Let's get down to work then, shall we?

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: George.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Like your father?

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: Like my father.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Not Albert?

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: Given the current situation...too Germanic.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: "Sirs, I here present unto you, GEORGE, your undoubted King!"

Speaker: cosmo lang
Dialogue: I've made inquiries.

Speaker: myrtle
Dialogue: A bit dry. Tried to keep it warm.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Mmm... Kedgeree! Lovely.

Speaker: myrtle
Dialogue: You look done in.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: I've news for you. You're coming to the Coronation.

Speaker: myrtle
Dialogue: I've news for you. I'm not!

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: You must.

Speaker: myrtle
Dialogue: Stand in the rain hoping for a glimpse?

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Royal Box. You and I.

Speaker: myrtle
Dialogue: Lionel...I'd need a new dress.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Rather thought you might.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Won't be a sec.

Speaker: cosmo lang
Dialogue: "The play's the thing, wherein I'll catch the conscience of a King."

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Bertie? Blast! Stepped on Lord Byron. Bertie...?

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: This is not a rehearsal, "Doctor" Logue.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Ah, the Star Chamber inquisition. I wondered when that would happen. And I'd promised Myrtle a new frock.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: "Just call me Lionel"! Never did you call yourself `Doctor'. We did that for you. No diploma, no training, no credentials. Just a great deal of nerve.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Want to hear my side of the story?

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: There isn't a "your-side-of-the-story". This is my story. And you've ruined it! Its not just the Coronation, terrifying enough, its the radio speech to millions afterwards, and the speech after that, and for the rest of my failed miserable life!

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Wembley Stadium...

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: You dare remind me?!

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: I was there.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: Then you knew from the start I was hopeless?!

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: My son, Valentine, asked, "Could you help that poor man?" I replied, "He's too old for me to manage a complete cure, but I could very nearly do it, I'm sure of that."

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: Lying bastard!

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: I knew I could help you. You refuse to believe?

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: In you?!

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: In yourself.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: Who the hell do you think you are?!

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: A failed actor.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: Actor?

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Father wanted me to be a doctor, but I couldn't cut flesh. So I worked in the mines, recited in pubs...

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: An actor?!

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: When the war came, by the time I was ready to be shipped out, the first casualties were limping home. Poor buggers, broken in bone and spirit. `Lionel, you're good with your mouth, see if you can help these poor sods.' The shell-shocked were the saddest. Most stuttered profoundly. Far worse than you. Muscle therapy helped somewhat, but I found I had to go deeper, as you might well imagine.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: I know nothing of those poor men!

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: I think you do. They had cried out, and the universe had not listened. So they'd lost faith in their voice. My job was to make them shout in righteous anger: "I have the right to be heard!"

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: I suppose that helped them, did it?

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Make inquiries.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: Inquiries have been made! No credentials.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: But a lot of success. No training was given.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: To Harley Street?!

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Cashed in our return tickets. I had three months rent.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: So you set yourself up on Harley Street as an actor? Harley Street, don't you know, is for doctors!

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: The plaque says, `L. Logue. Speech Specialist'. No mention of a medical degree. No mention of any degree. Some of the diggers I'd helped had come to England. They made referrals. My practice flourished. My acting, however, did not.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: Well enough to deceive me.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Lock me in the Tower.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: I would if I could!

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: What crime?

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: You've saddled this nation in its moment of peril with a voiceless King. Destroyed the happiness of my family...all for the sake of ensnaring a star client you knew you couldn't possibly assist!

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: I'm tired.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: You can't sit there!

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Why not? It's a chair.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: It's the Chair of Edward The Confessor! The throne upon which every King for six and a half centuries has been crowned.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: It's falling apart. People have carved their initials into it. Needs a stone to keep from blowing away.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: That's the Stone of Scone! The Stone of Destiny that was once Jacob's pillow.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: You believe such ballocks I don't care how many royal backsides have sat on it, it's a building block with handles attached. You're just like me, an actor with tawdry stage props you choose to believe are real.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: Listen to me... !

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Listen to you?! By what right?

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: Divine right, if you must! I'm your King!!!

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Noooo you're not! Told me so yourself. Said you didn't want it. So why should I listen to a poor stuttering bloke who can't put one word after another? Why waste my time listening to you?

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: Because I have a right to be heard!

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Heard as what?!

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: A man! I HAVE A VOICE!!!

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Well then...you're cured.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: Stop trying to squirm off the hook.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Bertie, you'll make a bloody good king. And you know it.

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Your Majesty?

Speaker: cosmo lang
Dialogue: You'll be relieved to learn I've found a replacement specialist. Impeccable credentials.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: That won't be necessary.

Speaker: cosmo lang
Dialogue: The matter's already been settled. For your own well-being.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: What did you say?

Speaker: cosmo lang
Dialogue: Your Majesty's function is to consult...and to be advised. You didn't consult, but you've just been advised.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: Now I advise you, so listen carefully. ...in this personal matter I will make my own decision.

Speaker: cosmo lang
Dialogue: May I remind you, you do not place the crown upon your own head.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: And may I remind you, it is my head upon which the crown is placed!

Speaker: cosmo lang
Dialogue: This will end badly.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: In hushed tones the BBC commentator paints a picture for the world, as you stand at the altar divested of your robes. Trumpets echo through the Abbey. The incessant rain clears miraculously as a shaft of sun streams through the stained-glass window catching your golden tunic and bathing you in light like a mediaeval knight. And you are King!

Speaker: winston churchill
Dialogue: Amidst a vitrine of glittering jewels, bobbing tiaras, and heaving bosoms.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: "In this grave hour... " Sorry.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Try again.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: "In this grave hour... "

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Turn the halts into pauses, during which you say to yourself, "God save the King".

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: I say that all the time, but apparently no one's listening.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Use the silence. Long pauses add solemnity to great occasions.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: Then I'm the solemnest king who ever lived. Lionel, I can't do this!

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Take it from the top. "In this grave hour..."

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: "In this grave hour, p-p-perhaps..."

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Go on...

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: The letter`P' is always difficult.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Get a running start, put the words all together. `Perhaps-the-most-fateful...'

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: "In this grave hour...perhaps-the-most- fateful...in our history..."

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Beaut.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: "... I send to every household of my peoples...both at home and overseas..."

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: "...this message... "

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: "...spoken with the same depth of feeling for each one of you... as if I were able..."

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: In your head, now: "Bugger, bugger, bugger! Damn, damn, damn! All those bloody blighters are going to have to listen to me!" Can you dance?

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Helps relax the body.  Waltz?

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: I prefer pipes.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Thought you might.  Dance with me. One, two, one-two-three- four. One, two, one- two-three-four. "For the second time..." one-two-three-four "... in the lives of most of us..." one, two, one-two-three- four "... we are at war." Three, four.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: "For the second time... in the lives of most of us... we are at war." One-two- three.  "Over and over again... we have tried to find a peaceful way... out of the differences... between ourselves... and those who are now our enemies." Bugger, bugger, bugger! Fuck, fuck, fuck!

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: You'll be ready.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: The shilling you won... still have it?

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: I'll return it.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Willie! Where's your mum?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: She had to work.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: You've been waiting here, alone, all this time?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: I heard the King.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Did you?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: He sang. And shouted rude words.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: He did.

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Why am I not surprised?

Speaker: floor manager
Dialogue: Think he'll manage?

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: `Walk up to the bloody thing boldly, stare it square in the eye, man to man.'

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: I already know. My father taught me.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: Bugger bugger bugger...bloody bloody bloody...

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Bertie, do make sure that's not switched on!

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: You're going to be splendid. And if you're not?

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: They'll bloody well have to listen to me anyway. Right?

Speaker: lionel
Dialogue: Bloody right.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Mr. Prime Minister, Your Grace, how kind of you to join us.

Speaker: cosmo lang
Dialogue: Wouldn't miss this for the world.  Congratulations. Neville didn't last long, did he? Talking to Hitler.

Speaker: winston churchill
Dialogue: My tenure will be shorter, if the King fails tonight.

Speaker: bertie
